sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Calculate the entropy change (ΔS) for the reaction below at 298 K:

2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(l)

Given the standard molar entropy values are:

H2(g) = 130.68 J/K mol

O2(g) = 205.03 J/K mol

H2O(l) = 69.91 J/K mol
message_2:
To calculate the entropy change (ΔS) for the reaction, we need to find the difference between the entropy of the products and the entropy of the reactants. The equation for this is:

ΔS = ΣnS(products) - ΣnS(reactants)

where n is the stoichiometric coefficient and S is the standard molar entropy.

For the given reaction:

ΔS = [2 × S(H2O(l))] - [2 × S(H2(g)) + S(O2(g))]

Now, we can plug in the given standard molar entropy values:

ΔS = [2 × 69.91 J/K mol] - [2 × 130.68 J/K mol + 205.03 J/K mol]

ΔS = [139.82 J/K mol] - [261.36 J/K mol + 205.03 J/K mol]

ΔS = 139.82 J/K mol - 466.39 J/K mol

ΔS = -326.57 J/K mol

The entropy change (ΔS) for the reaction is -326.57 J/K mol.
